name: Incremental Debt
definition: Umbrella family for incremental debt capacity concepts including free-and-clear capacity, ratio-based capacity, and builder mechanisms that allow borrowers to grow their accordion beyond closing-date levels.

children.definition: Simple fixed dollar basket without EBITDA alternative. A hard dollar cap with no growth mechanism. More restrictive than greater-of but simpler. Bank preferred position per DLS Row 9 is a fixed dollar amount subject to pro forma leverage compliance. Distinguished from greater-of by having no grower component.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Only

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (bank preferred fixed dollar structure)

children.definition: Free-and-clear EBITDA grower measured on the trailing four-quarter (last twelve months / LTM) EBITDA lookback. The LTM basis uses the most recent four consecutive fiscal quarters for which financial statements have been delivered, providing the most current measure of borrower performance. This is the standard measurement basis for grower baskets across all negative covenants. The LTM basis is neutral between borrower and lender — it reflects actual performance without forward-looking adjustments. Per PC Term Comparison lines 212-213, free-and-clear starters are '75-100% with 100% fairly standard,' and the EBITDA percentage grower operates on the LTM base to scale with borrower size.
children.name: LTM EBITDA Basis

children.definition: Free-and-clear EBITDA grower measured on a pro forma basis, giving effect to acquisitions, dispositions, and other material transactions as if they had occurred at the beginning of the measurement period, including permitted EBITDA add-backs (cost savings, synergies, non-recurring charges). Pro forma EBITDA is borrower-favorable because it inflates the measurement base with projected future benefits, increasing the free-and-clear capacity. Per DLS Preferred Row 72 (EBITDA), permitted add-backs include cost savings projected to be realized within 12 months, non-recurring expenses, and purchase accounting adjustments, each potentially increasing the EBITDA base and therefore the grower basket size.
children.name: Pro Forma EBITDA Basis

children.definition: Free-and-clear EBITDA grower based on EBITDA frozen at the closing date, providing a fixed measurement base that does not fluctuate with borrower performance. This is the most lender-protective EBITDA basis because it prevents the grower from increasing over time — the fixed dollar floor already provides capacity, and the frozen EBITDA percentage provides a known, non-expanding ceiling. However, it is also the most restrictive for borrowers, as a company that doubles its EBITDA would still have the same percentage-based capacity as at closing. This basis is uncommon in practice because it undermines the core purpose of the grower mechanism (scaling capacity with the business).
children.name: Closing Date EBITDA

children.definition: The EBITDA-based grower prong of the greater-of formula. Expressed as a percentage of LTM EBITDA, allowing the free-and-clear basket to grow as the business grows. Learning Material: '100% of EBITDA for the four quarter period preceding the determination date.' KCT Cat 2 Item 4 warns of high water marking: the basket 'permanently reset to the highest adjusted EBITDA reported even if EBITDA decreases afterwards.' PC Term Comparison: 75-100% EBITDA is standard with 100% fairly standard.

children.definition: The fixed dollar floor of the greater-of formula. Typically set at 100% of closing date EBITDA (a fixed number, not recalculated). Learning Material: '100% EBITDA as of the closing date (a fixed dollar amount).' Prevents the basket from shrinking below a guaranteed minimum even if EBITDA declines post-closing. In first lien/second lien deals, this floor is usually shared between credit agreements.

children.definition: Dominant market structure: the greater of a fixed dollar amount (typically 100% of closing date EBITDA) and a percentage of LTM EBITDA (typically 100%). Learning Material line 1412: 'Usually the greater of (x) 100% EBITDA as of the closing date (a fixed dollar amount) and (y) 100% of EBITDA for the four quarter period preceding the determination date.' PC Term Comparison: '75-100% with 100% fairly standard.' Provides both a floor (fixed dollar prevents shrinkage) and growth potential (LTM EBITDA scales with business performance).

children.definition: Free-and-clear capacity expressed solely as a percentage of EBITDA without a fixed dollar floor. In this structure, the free-and-clear amount fluctuates entirely with EBITDA — if EBITDA declines, the free-and-clear capacity shrinks to zero when EBITDA reaches zero. This structure is uncommon because it provides no minimum capacity floor, making the borrower unable to access the incremental facility during periods of financial distress when it may need liquidity most. The 'greater of' formulation (dollar floor + EBITDA grower) is standard precisely because it combines a guaranteed minimum with performance-based upside. Per PC Term Comparison lines 212-213, the standard is '75-100%' starter, implying a fixed-dollar base.
children.name: Percentage Only

children.definition: Fixed dollar amount providing guaranteed incremental debt capacity independent of financial performance. Typically sized at 75-100% of closing date EBITDA. Learning Material: 'the greater of (x) 100% EBITDA as of the closing date (a fixed dollar amount).' In first lien/second lien deals, this component is usually shared between the credit agreements. Distinguished from the EBITDA grower prong by being a static amount set at closing that does not change with subsequent EBITDA performance.

children.definition: Whether the free-and-clear basket capacity is shared between senior (first lien) and junior (second lien) incremental facilities, or whether each has its own dedicated pool. When shared, junior lien incremental debt incurred under the free-and-clear basket consumes capacity available for first lien incurrence, which is lender-favorable because it prevents the borrower from maximizing both senior and junior capacity. When separate, the borrower can incur the full free-and-clear amount as first lien AND a separate amount as junior lien. Per PC Term Comparison line 222: 'set at equivalent closing level; no headroom other than occasionally up to 0.25x for junior lien debt,' suggesting junior lien incremental operates with slightly more headroom but under the same capacity framework.
children.name: Senior/Junior Sharing

children.definition: Whether the free-and-clear basket capacity is shared with the incremental equivalent debt (IED) basket, meaning IED incurrences consume free-and-clear capacity and vice versa. When shared, total incremental capacity (facility + IED) cannot exceed the free-and-clear amount — the borrower chooses between facility and IED forms but draws from the same pool. When not shared, the borrower can potentially access free-and-clear capacity twice: once through the credit facility and again through IED. Per PC Term Comparison line 237 (MFN applies to): 'all pari debt including debt securities and IED,' confirming that IED and facility incremental are treated as part of the same capacity ecosystem.
children.name: Incremental Equivalent Debt Sharing

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Incremental Equivalent Debt permitted to be incurred in the form of senior secured notes or loans, either on a pari passu [NOTE: sometimes pari passu incremental equivalent debt only permitted in respect of notes] or junior basis, subordinated notes or loans or senior unsecured notes or loans and/or secured or unsecured mezzanine debt may be issued in lieu of the accordion, and any such debt shall be subject to the same terms and conditions as the incremental facility. No MFN on pari passu notes.
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Lender prefers prohibition; borrower seeks permission. Market typically allows with conditions.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No such basket

children.definition: Rules governing how shared free-and-clear capacity is allocated when the borrower incurs incremental debt across multiple facility types (term loan, revolver, IED, junior lien). Key mechanics include: (1) borrower election at time of incurrence (borrower designates which capacity pool the incurrence draws from), (2) FIFO or LIFO allocation (incurrences consume specific baskets in a defined order), (3) optimization election (borrower can retroactively redesignate which basket was consumed, per DLS Preferred Row 89 alternative terms on 'reclassification of baskets'). The allocation mechanics determine the borrower's ability to preserve specific basket types for future use.
children.name: Allocation Mechanics

children.definition: Whether unused capacity from other permitted debt baskets (general debt basket, Available Amount, investment baskets) can be reallocated to expand free-and-clear incremental capacity. Present in 11.3% of deals. Per PC Term Comparison lines 214-215: 'Typically no reallocation from general debt, general RP, general RDP or general investment baskets' — reallocation is the non-standard position. 'In Aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions may give general debt basket' — meaning even in the most sponsor-favorable deals, only the general debt basket may be reallocated. Reallocation is a significant capacity multiplier because it combines baskets that were designed to operate independently, potentially exceeding the intended aggregate capacity.
children.name: Unused Basket Reallocation
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 214-215 (no reallocation standard; general debt exception in Aggressive UMM/BSL)

children.definition: Whether free-and-clear capacity is shared between the incremental term facility and other facilities (revolving facility, IED, junior lien) or reserved exclusively for one tranche type. Shared capacity allows the borrower to allocate the basket across different facility types based on current needs. Per PC Term Comparison lines 214-215: 'Typically no reallocation from general debt, general RP, general RDP or general investment baskets' to incremental, and 'In Aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions may give general debt basket.' Sharing mechanics determine whether a single free-and-clear pool serves all incremental needs or whether each facility type has its own dedicated capacity.
children.name: Sharing Provisions

children.definition: In micro-market deals (under $50M EBITDA, corresponding to LMM per PC Term Comparison segments), free-and-clear amounts typically range $5-15M representing 50-100% of EBITDA. The outsized relative sizing reflects the minimum quantum needed for a meaningful incremental facility — below $5M, the incremental mechanism is practically unusable due to fixed transaction costs. Per PC Term Comparison lines 212-213, the starter is '75-100% with 100% fairly standard,' and for micro-market deals the fixed dollar floor often exceeds the EBITDA-based grower, making the floor the binding constraint. These deals typically feature MFN protection with no sunset (PCTC line 230) and existing lender ROFR (PCTC line 253: 'Common in CMM and LMM transactions').
children.name: Micro Market (<$50M EBITDA)

children.definition: In middle-market deals ($50-500M EBITDA, corresponding to CMM and UMM per PC Term Comparison segments), free-and-clear amounts typically range $20-50M representing 10-40% of EBITDA. More proportional sizing reflects deeper capital markets access — borrowers can obtain financing through multiple channels (bank market, private credit, high yield) rather than relying solely on the incremental facility. Per PC Term Comparison lines 212-213, the starter is '75-100% with 100% fairly standard.' MFN norms vary: PCTC line 229 notes sunset '12-18 months' for Aggressive UMM/BSL vs 'no sunset' otherwise; PCTC line 231 notes '50 bps standard' even for Aggressive UMM/BSL.

children.definition: In large-cap deals ($500M+ EBITDA, corresponding to BSL per PC Term Comparison segments), free-and-clear amounts typically range $50-150M at lower percentages of EBITDA (10-30%). The lower relative sizing reflects the availability of alternative debt instruments (high-yield notes, IED, ratio debt) that large-cap borrowers can use in addition to the incremental facility. Per PC Term Comparison lines 228-240, Aggressive UMM/BSL deals feature: MFN sunset at 12-18 months (line 229), MFN capped at 50% of EBITDA (line 233), MFN applies only to pari term loans (line 236), and inside maturity exception up to 50-100% of EBITDA (line 249). These wider permissions reduce the incremental facility's importance relative to alternative debt sources.
children.name: Large Cap ($500M+ EBITDA)

children.definition: Risk concern per Key Credit Terms Cat 2 Item 4 (High Water Marking for Grower Baskets): grower baskets permanently reset to the highest EBITDA ever reported, never decreasing even after asset sales or underperformance. This creates a one-way ratchet where the free-and-clear capacity reflects peak EBITDA rather than current EBITDA, potentially providing substantial capacity during periods of financial distress. Alternative grower metrics that compound this risk include: total assets (which may grow through acquisition), revenue (which can be inflated by unprofitable growth), and net assets (which can be manipulated through accounting changes). Per PC Term Comparison (EBITDA correlation framework), the standard grower uses LTM EBITDA, but high-water-mark provisions override the LTM lookback with historical peaks.
children.name: Alternative Grower Metrics

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – high water mark ratchet

children.definition_source: Key Credit Terms Cat 2 Item 4 (high water marking for grower baskets)

children.definition: Correlation between deal EBITDA size and the fixed free-and-clear dollar amount. Larger deals with higher EBITDA typically negotiate proportionally larger baskets, though the relationship is not linear — micro-market deals have outsized baskets relative to EBITDA while large-cap deals have smaller relative baskets. Per PC Term Comparison lines 212-213, the standard starter is '75-100% with 100% fairly standard,' establishing the EBITDA correlation as approximately 1:1 for the EBITDA grower component. The fixed dollar floor sets the minimum, while the grower provides the scaling mechanism. The correlation reflects market norms for each segment: LMM (<$50M), CMM ($50-100M), UMM (>$100M), and BSL, each with different expectations for free-and-clear sizing.
children.name: EBITDA Size Correlation

children.definition: Mechanism by which free-and-clear capacity is restored or refreshed upon specified events — typically an amendment or extension that resets the free-and-clear basket to its original level or a new higher level. The refresher effectively gives the borrower a new free-and-clear basket after the event, regardless of how much prior capacity has been consumed. This is sponsor-favorable because it allows the borrower to access the full free-and-clear amount again after each qualifying event. Per PC Term Comparison lines 212-215 (no specific refresher noted), refresher provisions are not standard and represent an incremental concession beyond the typical free-and-clear framework.
children.name: Refresher Mechanism

children.definition: Automatic adjustment mechanism that increases free-and-clear capacity based on specified performance metrics beyond standard EBITDA growth. Dynamic adjustments may be tied to: (1) EBITDA growth above a threshold (step-up provisions), (2) ESG or sustainability metrics (sustainability-linked basket increases), or (3) credit rating improvements. These adjustments go beyond the standard grower (which scales automatically with EBITDA) by providing bonus capacity for specific achievements. Dynamic adjustments are a newer market development, particularly ESG-linked provisions that reward borrowers for meeting sustainability targets. Not addressed in DLS Preferred or PC Term Comparison, confirming their status as non-standard, emerging-market features.
children.name: Dynamic Adjustment

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred and PC Term Comparison (neither addresses dynamic adjustments — confirms non-standard)

children.definition: Whether the EBITDA grower component is permanently reset to the highest EBITDA ever reported by the borrower, preventing downward adjustment even after asset sales, business deterioration, or other events that reduce current EBITDA. Per Key Credit Terms Cat 2 Item 4 (High Water Marking for Grower Baskets), this is a risk item requiring escalation. The high water mark creates a one-way ratchet: if a borrower reports $100M EBITDA in year 1 and then declines to $60M in year 2, the grower still provides capacity based on $100M. This is particularly dangerous in combination with distress scenarios — the borrower has maximum capacity precisely when its financial position is weakest. Standard practice is LTM EBITDA without high water mark.
children.name: High Water Mark / EBITDA Ratchet

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – high water mark ratchet

children.definition_source: Key Credit Terms Cat 2 Item 4 (high water marking as risk)

children.definition: The EBITDA-based component of the free-and-clear basket that causes capacity to scale with borrower performance, ensuring the incremental facility remains proportionally available as the business grows. Expressed as a percentage of LTM Consolidated EBITDA in a 'greater of' formulation with the fixed dollar floor. Per PC Term Comparison lines 212-213, the standard starter is '75-100% with 100% fairly standard,' meaning the grower typically provides capacity equal to 75-100% of current EBITDA. Per DLS Preferred Row 89 (Other Covenant Considerations alternative terms): 'Dollar baskets to also include a grower based on EBITDA or Total Assets' — confirming the grower mechanism as a sponsor-favorable feature across all negative covenant baskets, not just incremental.

children.definition: The fixed/formulaic dollar amount of incremental debt capacity available without meeting any financial ratio test, forming the guaranteed minimum accordion capacity. Learning Material: 'Usually the greater of (x) 100% EBITDA as of the closing date (a fixed dollar amount) and (y) 100% of EBITDA for the four quarter period preceding the determination date (LTM EBITDA). Basket can grow over time with growth of EBITDA. Often there is flex to reduce both prongs to 75%.' PC Term Comparison: '75-100% with 100% fairly standard.' DLS Preferred Row 9 establishes a different structure: fixed dollar plus voluntary prepayment builder, subject to closing-date leverage compliance. Distinguished from the ratio prong (which requires pro forma leverage compliance) by providing capacity regardless of the borrower's financial condition.

children.definition_source: Learning Material lines 1412-1416; PC Term Comparison Incremental section line 213; DLS Preferred Row 9

children.definition: First lien leverage ratio test set at the closing date leverage level, providing certainty for both borrower and lenders but limiting incremental capacity if leverage subsequently declines below closing levels. Per PC Term Comparison line 222: leverage levels 'set at equivalent closing level,' confirming closing-date-ratio as the standard. This approach locks in the incremental capacity negotiated at closing — the borrower can always incur incremental debt if pro forma leverage does not exceed closing leverage. The limitation is that deleveraging does not create additional capacity, which penalizes well-performing borrowers who reduce leverage through EBITDA growth or debt paydown.
children.name: Closing Date Ratio
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 222 (leverage at closing level)

children.definition: First lien leverage ratio test set at a fixed absolute level (e.g., 4.0x First Lien Net Leverage Ratio) regardless of the borrower's closing date leverage. The fixed ratio may be set higher or lower than closing leverage depending on deal dynamics. When set higher, it provides more capacity than the closing-date approach; when lower, it is more restrictive. Fixed ratios are less common than closing-date ratios because they decouple the incremental capacity from the deal's original leverage metrics. Per PC Term Comparison line 222, the standard is 'set at equivalent closing level,' making fixed absolute ratios a departure from market norms.
children.name: Fixed Ratio Level
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 222 (closing level standard — fixed ratio as departure)

children.definition: First lien leverage ratio threshold for incremental capacity that decreases over time on a pre-negotiated schedule, mirroring the financial maintenance covenant step-down schedule. As the financial covenant tightens (e.g., from 5.0x at closing to 4.5x after 18 months), the incremental ratio test tightens proportionally. This approach maintains a consistent relationship between the financial covenant headroom and the incremental capacity — the borrower always has the same relative flexibility to incur incremental debt regardless of the covenant cycle. Per DLS Preferred Row 73 (Financial Covenant): 'step downs' are the standard covenant structure, and mirroring them in the incremental framework creates consistency.
children.name: Step-Down Schedule
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (Financial Covenant — step-downs standard)

children.definition: Leverage threshold for pari passu secured incremental debt. Learning Material: 'First lien leverage ratio prong is usually opening first lien leverage ratio (closing date leverage after giving effect to the Transactions). If the proposed ratio is outside (higher than) the opening first lien leverage, flag it.' DLS Preferred Row 9: 'a Senior Net Leverage Ratio not to exceed the Senior Net Leverage Ratio on the Closing Date.' PC Term Comparison: set at equivalent closing level. Distinguished from junior lien and unsecured tiers by applying the most restrictive ratio to the most senior debt.
children.name: First Lien Leverage Test
children.definition_source: Learning Material line 1443; DLS Preferred Row 9; PC Term Comparison line 222

children.definition: Leverage threshold for junior lien secured incremental debt, using total secured leverage ratio. Learning Material: 'Total secured ratio prong is usually opening total secured leverage ratio plus some cushion.' DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative: 'in the case of junior lien indebtedness, the Secured Net Leverage Ratio would be no greater than closing date Secured Net Leverage.' PC Term Comparison: 'up to 0.25x for junior lien.' Distinguished from first lien tier by using a broader (total secured) ratio with a cushion.
children.name: Junior Lien Leverage Test
children.definition_source: Learning Material lines 1447-1449; DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative; PC Term Comparison line 222

children.definition: Leverage threshold for unsecured incremental debt, using total leverage ratio or interest/fixed charge coverage ratio at borrower's election. Learning Material: unsecured is 'Total leverage ratio or Interest/fixed charge coverage ratio or Best of either ratio.' DLS Preferred alternative: 'the Total Net Leverage Ratio would be no greater than closing date Total Net Leverage or pro forma compliance with a 2.0x cash interest coverage ratio.' PC Term Comparison: '0.25-0.50x for unsecured.' Distinguished from secured tiers by allowing a coverage ratio alternative.
children.name: Unsecured Debt Ratio Test

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: No explicit borrower position stated
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market likely follows lender-preferred position (no borrower alternative documented)
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Unsecured incremental subject to Total Net Leverage not exceeding closing-date level OR 2.0x cash interest coverage

Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Scope
Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Ratio Basket

children.definition_source: Learning Material line 1441; DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative; PC Term Comparison line 222

children.definition: Separate leverage ratio thresholds by debt seniority level, allowing different amounts of capacity at each tier. Learning Material: first lien at opening FLLR, junior lien at opening secured + cushion, unsecured at opening total + cushion or 2.0x FCCR. PC Term Comparison: 'set at equivalent closing level; no headroom other than occasionally up to 0.25x for junior lien and 0.25-0.50x for unsecured.'
children.name: Ratio Tiering by Seniority
children.definition_source: Learning Material lines 1437-1441; PC Term Comparison line 222

children.definition: Whether the leverage ratio is tested on a pro forma basis giving effect to (1) the incremental debt incurrence itself (increasing the debt numerator), (2) the intended use of proceeds (e.g., acquisition EBITDA increasing the denominator), and (3) any simultaneous transactions (dispositions reducing debt, refinancings shifting debt between tranches). Pro forma testing is standard for all incurrence-based ratio tests and is the only method that provides a meaningful forward-looking capacity assessment. Per DLS Preferred Row 89 (alternative terms), 'excluding simultaneous fixed amount incurrences when calculating leverage ratios' is a sponsor-favorable convention that reduces the numerator by not counting the free-and-clear amount in the pro forma calculation.
children.name: Pro Forma Calculation
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 89 (simultaneous fixed-amount exclusion)

children.definition: Whether proceeds of the incremental facility (cash received from the new borrowing) can be netted from total debt in the ratio calculation numerator, reducing the apparent leverage and making the test easier to satisfy. Addressed in 47.8% of incremental provisions; standard: cannot net proceeds. Proceeds netting is borrower-favorable because it treats the incremental cash as an immediate offset to the new debt, even though the cash will be deployed for its intended purpose (acquisition, working capital, etc.) and not retained as a permanent debt reduction. Without netting, the full amount of the new debt is included in the ratio numerator, which is the economically accurate treatment. Per PC Term Comparison line 222, leverage is 'set at equivalent closing level,' implying no proceeds netting.
children.name: Proceeds Netting

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: No explicit borrower position stated
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market likely follows lender-preferred position (no borrower alternative documented)
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Cash proceeds of incremental being incurred NOT netted for leverage ratio calculation; prevents circular capacity creation

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 222 (closing level — implies no netting)

children.definition: Whether all incremental revolving commitments and delayed draw term loan (DDTL) commitments are assumed to be fully drawn when testing the leverage ratio, even if only a portion has been actually borrowed. Standard: yes for revolvers and DDTLs — the fully-drawn assumption is the conservative approach because it measures maximum potential leverage rather than current leverage. Without the fully-drawn assumption, a borrower could establish a large incremental revolver, satisfy the ratio test at a low draw level, and then draw the full amount at a leverage level that exceeds the test threshold. Per DLS Preferred Row 73 (Financial Covenant alternative — covenant-lite): LC and revolver treatment in testing already contemplates fully-drawn assumptions.
children.name: Fully Drawn Assumption

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: No explicit borrower position stated
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market likely follows lender-preferred position (no borrower alternative documented)
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Revolving and DDTL commitments assumed fully drawn for ratio test; no exclusion of undrawn commitments from leverage calc

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (covenant-lite — revolver/LC testing assumptions)

children.definition: Whether unrestricted cash and cash equivalents can be netted from total debt in the leverage ratio numerator (creating 'net' leverage metrics: First Lien Net Leverage, Secured Net Leverage, Total Net Leverage). Cash netting is standard in most leveraged credit agreements for covenant testing purposes. The risk is that borrowers can inflate cash netting by (1) incurring incremental debt and holding the proceeds as cash temporarily, artificially reducing net leverage, or (2) drawing on revolving facilities shortly before the test date to increase cash on hand. Per DLS Preferred Row 73 (Financial Covenant): 'Total [Net] Leverage Ratio' and 'Senior [Secured] [Net] Leverage Ratio' — the '[Net]' notation indicates cash netting is a negotiated term, not automatic.
children.name: Cash Netting Rules
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (Financial Covenant — [Net] leverage as negotiated term)

INCREMENTAL_NETTING.label: Incremental Netting

children.definition: Rules governing how the pro forma leverage ratio is computed when testing incremental ratio basket capacity, including pro forma adjustments, proceeds netting, fully-drawn assumptions, and cash netting. The calculation methodology can significantly affect whether the ratio test is satisfied — aggressive calculation conventions (netting proceeds, netting cash) create more capacity, while conservative conventions create less. Per DLS Preferred Row 89 (Other Covenant Considerations alternative terms): 'Excluding simultaneous fixed amount incurrences when calculating leverage ratios' — this convention would exclude free-and-clear incurrences from the ratio calculation, artificially lowering the leverage used for the ratio test.
children.name: Calculation Mechanics
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 89 (excluding simultaneous fixed-amount incurrences from ratio calculation)

children.definition: Feature of the no-worse prong providing unlimited dollar capacity — there is no fixed dollar ceiling, and the borrower can incur any amount of incremental debt as long as the pro forma leverage ratio does not exceed the closing date level. This is the most aggressive formulation because it combines unlimited sizing with a relative (rather than absolute) ratio test. Per PC Term Comparison lines 217-218, the no-worse prong is 'very atypical even in Aggressive UMM/BSL transactions,' and the unlimited capacity feature represents the outer boundary of sponsor-favorable terms. Even when the no-worse prong is agreed, unlimited capacity may be constrained by practical limitations (new lender willingness to lend at the prevailing leverage level).
children.name: Unlimited at Closing Leverage

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: No explicit borrower position stated
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market likely follows lender-preferred position (no borrower alternative documented)
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No unlimited capacity via no-worse test; reject argument that any amount passes if leverage is already below closing-date ratio

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 217-218 (no-worse very atypical)

children.definition: Restriction limiting the no-worse prong to incremental incurrences made in connection with a permitted acquisition, preventing its use for general-purpose borrowing. Per PC Term Comparison lines 217-218: 'if agreed limit it to acquisitions.' The acquisition limitation addresses the primary concern with the no-worse prong — that it creates unlimited capacity at elevated leverage levels — by restricting its use to transactions that are expected to generate additional EBITDA (through the acquired business), thereby maintaining the leverage ratio even as debt increases. General-purpose borrowing under the no-worse prong would increase debt without a corresponding EBITDA increase, making leverage preservation less likely.
children.name: Acquisition-Only Limitation

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Can be expanded to include “irrevocable” restricted payments and restricted debt prepayments for which an irrevocable notice has been sent. Some Sponsors also permitted to use this concept for any transaction regardless of conditionality not requiring financing or “irrevocable” nature of the transaction [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market landing between lender-preferred and borrower-aggressive positions; specific terms deal-dependent.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No-worse prong limited to acquisitions not conditioned on financing; LCA testing unavailable for ratio incurrence and financial covenant

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 217-218 (no-worse — if agreed, limit to acquisitions)

children.definition: Whether the closing date leverage used as the floor for the no-worse test is measured on a gross basis (total debt divided by EBITDA) or net basis (total debt minus unrestricted cash divided by EBITDA), and which EBITDA period is used for the measurement (closing-date EBITDA vs. LTM EBITDA at time of test). Net basis is borrower-favorable because netting cash reduces the apparent leverage floor. Using closing-date EBITDA (which may include projected synergies and add-backs per DLS Preferred Row 72) rather than actual LTM EBITDA further inflates the denominator, lowering the effective leverage floor and making the no-worse test easier to satisfy.
children.name: Measurement Basis

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: No explicit borrower position stated
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market likely follows lender-preferred position (no borrower alternative documented)

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 72 (EBITDA add-backs affecting measurement basis); PC Term Comparison lines 217-218 (no-worse prong)

children.definition: Alternative ratio test allowing unlimited incremental incurrence if pro forma leverage does not exceed closing date leverage, regardless of the absolute leverage level. Per PC Term Comparison line 217-218: 'No worse prongs: Very atypical even in Aggressive UMM/BSL transactions; if agreed limit it to acquisitions.' The no-worse prong is a sponsor-favorable alternative to the absolute ratio test because it measures relative change rather than absolute level — if closing leverage was 5.0x and current leverage is 6.0x, the no-worse test would permit incurrence that keeps leverage at 6.0x, while an absolute test set at 5.0x would prohibit it. This creates unlimited capacity in distress scenarios where leverage has risen above closing levels.
children.name: No-Worse-Than-Closing Prong

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: No explicit borrower position stated
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market likely follows lender-preferred position (no borrower alternative documented)
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: No no-worse prong; all ratio-based incurrence must satisfy fixed closing-date leverage cap, not just be no worse than pre-incurrence

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 217-218 (no-worse very atypical, limit to acquisitions)

children.definition: First Lien Net Leverage Ratio: first lien secured debt minus unrestricted cash and cash equivalents, divided by LTM Consolidated EBITDA. The most common metric for testing pari passu incremental capacity because it measures the leverage attributable specifically to first lien claims on the collateral, excluding junior lien and unsecured debt that do not compete for first lien collateral recovery. Per PC Term Comparison line 222: leverage at closing level for first lien incremental. Per DLS Preferred Row 73 (Financial Covenant): 'Senior [Secured] [Net] Leverage Ratio with step downs' — the financial covenant may use a slightly different metric (Senior Secured vs First Lien), but the concepts are closely related.
children.name: First Lien Net Leverage Ratio

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Allow side by side revolvers (if permitted must have ROFR and/or pro rata borrowing and prepayments; MFN protection)
Include builder for permanent commitment reductions under the Revolving Facility
(a) the sum (the “Free and Clear Incremental Amount”) of [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market landing between lender-preferred and borrower-aggressive positions; specific terms deal-dependent.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: First Lien Net Leverage as primary pari passu test; broadest indebtedness definition with capped cash netting

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (Senior Secured Net Leverage — related metric); PC Term Comparison line 222 (closing level for first lien)

children.definition: Secured Net Leverage Ratio: all secured debt (first lien plus junior lien) minus unrestricted cash and cash equivalents, divided by LTM Consolidated EBITDA. Used for testing incremental capacity where the incurrence may be at junior lien priority — the secured net metric captures the full impact on the collateral package regardless of lien priority. Per DLS Preferred Row 73: 'Senior [Secured] [Net] Leverage Ratio' is a standard financial covenant metric. Per PC Term Comparison line 222, junior lien incremental may have '0.25x' headroom above the first lien test level, and the secured net metric measures the combined first-lien-plus-junior-lien leverage.
children.name: Secured Net Leverage Ratio

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Limited to debt for borrowed money capital lease obligations/purchase money debt and obligations evidenced by bonds, debentures notes and similar instruments
No cap on cash netting
No requirement to keep the unrestricted cash in deposit account subject to a control agreement [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Secured Net Leverage limited to debt secured by any assets, not just Collateral; cash netting with deposit account control agreements

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio); PC Term Comparison line 222 (0.25x junior headroom)

children.definition: Total Net Leverage Ratio: all debt (secured and unsecured) minus unrestricted cash and cash equivalents, divided by LTM Consolidated EBITDA. Used for testing unsecured and subordinated incremental capacity because it measures the borrower's total leverage regardless of the debt's security status. Per DLS Preferred Row 73: 'Total [Net] Leverage Ratio with step downs' is a standard financial covenant metric. Per PC Term Comparison line 222, unsecured incremental may have '0.25-0.50x' headroom above the closing leverage level, reflecting the lower risk of unsecured debt to the senior lender's collateral position. Total net leverage includes all obligations that appear as debt on the balance sheet.
children.name: Total Net Leverage Ratio

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Limited to debt for borrowed money capital lease obligations/purchase money debt and obligations evidenced by bonds, debentures notes and similar instruments
No cap on cash netting
No requirement to keep the unrestricted cash in deposit account subject to a control agreement [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Total Net Leverage with capped cash netting; unrestricted cash limited to amounts in controlled deposit accounts

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 73 (Total Net Leverage Ratio); PC Term Comparison line 222 (0.25-0.50x unsecured headroom)

children.definition: Interest Coverage Ratio: EBITDA divided by total interest expense for the measurement period. An alternative incurrence test for unsecured incremental debt that measures debt service capacity rather than absolute leverage. Per PC Term Comparison line 220: 'Interest coverage test: Typically rejected.' Interest coverage is a less reliable metric for incremental capacity because it can be satisfied even at very high leverage levels if the borrower generates sufficient cash flow relative to interest cost — a borrower at 10x leverage with low interest rates could still satisfy a 2.0x coverage test. When available, typical minimum threshold is 2.0x. Per DLS Preferred Row 73 (Financial Covenant): 'Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio' is listed as a potential maintenance covenant, a related concept.
children.name: Interest Coverage Ratio

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Allow side by side revolvers (if permitted must have ROFR and/or pro rata borrowing and prepayments; MFN protection)
Include builder for permanent commitment reductions under the Revolving Facility
(a) the sum (the “Free and Clear Incremental Amount”) of [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market landing between lender-preferred and borrower-aggressive positions; specific terms deal-dependent.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Interest coverage test as alternative to leverage for unsecured incurrence only; minimum 2.0x cash interest coverage

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 220 (interest coverage typically rejected); DLS Preferred Row 73 (Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio as potential covenant)

children.definition: Identification of which leverage ratio definition is used for the incremental ratio test, which significantly affects available capacity because different metrics include different debt in the numerator. Per PC Term Comparison line 222, leverage levels are 'set at equivalent closing level' with '0.25x for junior lien debt and 0.25-0.50x for unsecured debt' — implying different ratio metrics for different debt types. Common metrics: (1) First Lien Net Leverage (most restrictive — only first lien debt, most relevant for pari passu incurrence), (2) Secured Net Leverage (all secured debt — relevant for junior lien), (3) Total Net Leverage (all debt — relevant for unsecured), and (4) Interest Coverage (EBITDA/interest — alternative for unsecured per PCTC line 220, 'typically rejected').
children.name: Leverage Metric Selection

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position:
Limited to debt for borrowed money capital lease obligations/purchase money debt and obligations evidenced by bonds, debentures notes and similar instruments
No cap on cash netting
No requirement to keep the unrestricted cash in deposit account subject to a control agreement [...]
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Spectrum from fixed-dollar cap (lender) to ratio-based (borrower). Market often lands on greater-of formulation.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Broad Total Indebtedness definition including borrowed money, purchase money, capital leases, guarantees, and LCs; cash netting capped

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 220, 222 (leverage levels and metrics by debt type)

children.name: No-Worse-For-Acquisitions Test
children.definition: Alternative ratio test permitting incremental debt incurrence in connection with permitted acquisitions where pro forma leverage does not exceed closing-date leverage, even if absolute leverage exceeds the standard ratio test threshold. Per PC Term Comparison lines 217-218: 'No worse prongs: Very atypical even in Aggressive UMM/BSL transactions; if agreed limit it to acquisitions.' This acquisition-specific no-worse test recognizes that acquisitions generate additional EBITDA that may maintain leverage ratios even as absolute debt increases. Per DLS Preferred Row 82 (Permitted Acquisitions), acquisitions are subject to detailed conditions including leverage ratio compliance — the no-worse-acquisitions prong provides an alternative test that may be less restrictive than the standard acquisition leverage conditions.
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison lines 217-218 (no-worse limited to acquisitions); DLS Preferred Row 82 (Permitted Acquisitions leverage conditions)

children.name: Interest Coverage Ratio Alternative
children.definition: Alternative incurrence test permitting unsecured or junior-lien incremental debt when the borrower can demonstrate pro forma compliance with a minimum interest coverage ratio (typically 2.0x coverage). Per PC Term Comparison line 220: 'Interest coverage test: Typically rejected.' When available, this alternative provides a second path to incurrence — if the leverage ratio test fails but the borrower generates sufficient cash flow relative to interest expense, it can still incur incremental debt. The interest coverage alternative is most relevant for lower-rated credits where leverage ratios are elevated but cash generation is strong, and for unsecured debt where the leverage metric (total net) may be less relevant than the borrower's ability to service the additional interest burden.
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 220 (interest coverage typically rejected)

children.definition: Unlimited incremental debt capacity available subject to pro forma compliance with leverage ratio tests, tiered by debt seniority. Learning Material: 'Incremental facility is permitted if after giving effect thereto a specified ratio is not exceeded.' Typical tiering: first lien secured at opening FLLR, junior lien at opening secured leverage + 0.25x cushion, unsecured at opening total leverage + 0.50x cushion or 2.0x interest coverage (DLS Preferred Row 9 alternative). PC Term Comparison: 'set at equivalent closing level; no headroom other than occasionally up to 0.25x for junior lien and 0.25-0.50x for unsecured.' Distinguished from free-and-clear (which requires no financial test) by being available only when leverage allows.

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9; Learning Material line 1425

children.definition: Mechanism by which voluntary prepayment of junior, unsecured, or subordinated debt restores incremental pari passu capacity by reducing the outstanding secured debt used in the ratio calculation. Per Key Credit Terms Cat 4 Item 9: 'Ability to add to incremental pari capacity by paying down junior, unsecured or subordinated debt.' This is a risk item because it allows the borrower to artificially create first lien capacity by retiring cheaper subordinated debt — effectively converting junior capacity into senior capacity. The concern is that borrowers use available cash to prepay junior debt not to reduce overall leverage but to manufacture headroom for additional first lien borrowing. Per PC Term Comparison line 216: 'Avoid up-tiering for voluntary prepayment prong; credit only for amounts paid.'
children.name: capacity restoration on paydown
children.definition_source: Key Credit Terms Cat 4 Item 9 (junior debt paydown restoring pari capacity); PC Term Comparison line 216 (avoid up-tiering for voluntary prepayment prong)

children.name: Qualifying Junior Debt Types
children.definition: Types of debt whose voluntary prepayment qualifies for the junior debt credit mechanism that restores incremental pari passu capacity: (1) second lien / junior lien debt, (2) unsecured debt (including high-yield notes), and (3) subordinated debt (mezzanine, seller notes). Per PC Term Comparison line 216: 'credit only for amounts paid' — the credit should equal only the dollar amount actually prepaid, not the face amount of the retired debt (relevant when debt is purchased at a discount in the secondary market). Per Key Credit Terms Cat 4 Item 9, the qualifying types should be clearly delineated to prevent the borrower from claiming credit for retiring operational or intercompany debt that does not meaningfully reduce the capital structure.
children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison line 216 (credit only for amounts paid); Key Credit Terms Cat 4 Item 9 (junior debt paydown risk)

children.definition: Whether junior/unsecured/subordinated debt prepayments build first-lien capacity. KCT Cat 4 Item 9: 'Ability to add to incremental pari capacity by paying down junior, unsecured or subordinated debt.' Learning Material: 'Prepayment of second lien, unsecured or non-first lien debt should not increase first lien capacity.' This is an up-tiering risk. Distinguished from TL-only scope by crossing lien priority boundaries.

children.definition: Dollar-for-dollar capacity increase based on voluntary prepayments of funded debt. Learning Material: 'Should be limited to voluntary prepayments. Should exclude prepayments made with long-term debt: refinancing with long-term debt is not a de-leveraging event. Flag if discounted buybacks are given credit for the full face amount.' PC Term Comparison: 'Avoid up-tiering for voluntary prepayment prong; credit only for amounts paid.' Distinguished from the commitment reduction builder (which relates to revolver reductions) by rebuilding term loan capacity.

children.definition: Retained excess cash flow (ECF not swept to lenders) builds incremental capacity. DLS Preferred Row 86 establishes the Available Amount builder starting with 'the percentage of Excess Cash Flow not taken into account in calculating the ECF prepayment.' This may cross over to build incremental capacity in aggressive deals. Distinguished from voluntary prepayment builder by being a passive accumulation rather than an active paydown.

Distinguished from the contribution debt mechanism (which creates a new debt basket) by directly adding to accordion capacity.
